Determining relative affinities of protein-DNA interactions

sequences are readily measured using the gel retardation assay.

Under these conditions, the protein distributes between the
two DNA species as a function of its affinites for each. The
proportion of each DNA fragment that is bound versus free is
directly quantitated by densitometry or scintilation counting,
yielding a measurment of relative affinity. Although not part
of our lab excercise, it is important to note that the gel retar-
dation assay can also be used to determine the fraction of
protein that is active for DNA binding, as well as its absolute
equilibrium binding constant for a given DNA fragment (see
auxiliary handouts).
